This manual supersedes IRM 4.75.35, “Fraud and Abusive Transaction Procedures” dated August 19, 2016. It also updates, consolidates and obsoletes IRM 4.90.15,“ Federal State and Local Governments, FSLG Fraud Procedures”. Includes IG memo “TE/GE -04-0420-0004”, Paperless Closings, issued April 23, 2020. Includes IG memo “TE/GE- 04-0819-0015, Consolidated Policy Statements and Delegation Orders Into two New IRM Sections, Dated 08/23/2019.

) Purpose: This IRM provides procedures and guidelines for considering tax fraud (hereinafter referred to as “fraud” unless stated otherwise), identifying and elements of fraud, and developing fraud issues. This IRM also provides in- struction on compliance actions involving cases where fraud and abusive transactions and other noncompliance matters are involved. (
) Audience: Tax Exempt and Government Entities Exempt Organizations and Government Entities Examinations (
) Policy Owner: The Fraud Enforcement Office is responsible for fraud policy. Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) is responsible for overseeing fraud. (
) Program Owner: EO/GE is responsible for overseeing the fraud program for exempt organizations and government entities. (
) Contact Information To recommend changes or make any other this IRM section, e-mail the EO Examinations Mandatory Review office at *TEGE EO Review Staff. (

) The primary objective of the fraud program is to foster compliance through recommendation of criminal prosecutions and civil penalties against who evade the assessment and payment of taxes known to be due and (

) Generally, for fraud to be present, the examiner must show either: a. An additional tax due and owing as the result of an intent to evade or b. The willful and material submission of false statements or false documents in connection with an application or return. (

) The Fraud Technical Advisor (FTA) plays a vital role in the development of a potential fraud case. Along with the TE/GE Fraud Specialist (TFS), consult the FTA in all cases involving potential criminal fraud, as well as those that have potential for a civil fraud penalty. The FTA serves as a resource liaison to compliance employees in all operating divisions. The FTA is to assist you in fraud investigations and offer advice on matters concerning fraud. (

) Fraud is deception by misrepresentation of material facts, or silence when good faith requires expression, which results in material damage to one who Fraud relies on it and has the right to rely on it. Simply stated, it is obtaining something of value from someone else through deceit. (

) Speciﬁcally, tax fraud is often deﬁned as an intentional wrongdoing, on the part of a taxpayer, with the speciﬁc purpose of evading a tax known or believed to be owing. Tax fraud requires both: • A tax due and owing and • Fraudulent intent (

) Familiarize yourself with the following legal terms to understand the require- ments of proof: - Other a. Burden of Proof - the obligation to offer evidence that a court (judge jury) could reasonably believe in support of a contention. In tax fraud cases, the burden of proof is on the Government. b. Evidence - data presented to a judge or jury in proof of the facts in and, which may include the testimony of witnesses, records, or objects. Evidence is distinguished from proof, in that, proof is the result or effect of evidence. c. Direct Evidence - evidence, which if believed, proves existence of fact issue without inference or presumption. Examples include testimony a witness who actually saw, heard or touched the subject of or documents that establish on their face the occurrence of an event (e.g., a check shows that the drafter transferred speciﬁc funds to a speciﬁc person on a speciﬁc date). d. Circumstantial Evidence - evidence based on inference and not observation. e. Presumption (of law) - a rule of law that a judge or jury will draw a ticular inference from a particular fact, or from particular evidence, and until the truth of such inference is disproved. f. Inference - a logical conclusion from given facts. g. Preponderance of Evidence - evidence that will incline an impartial to one side rather than the other so as to remove the cause from the realm of speculation. It does not relate merely to the quantity of evidence. Simply stated, evidence, which is more convincing than the evidence offered in opposition. h. Reasonable Doubt - a doubt that would cause a prudent person to hesitate before acting in matters of importance to themselves. Such a doubt will leave a juror’s mind uncertain after examination of the evidence. i. Willful Intent to Defraud - an intentional wrongdoing with the speciﬁc purpose of evading a tax believed by the taxpayer to be owing.

j. Clear and Convincing Evidence - evidence showing that the assertion made is highly probable or reasonably certain. This is a greater burden proof than preponderance of the evidence but less than beyond a able doubt. (
) Understanding the requirements of proof is essential in establishing fraud. all criminal and civil tax fraud cases, the burden of proof is on the of Proof (

) The major difference between civil and criminal fraud is the degree of proof required. a. In civil fraud cases, the Government must prove fraud by clear and convincing evidence. b. In criminal cases, the Government must present sufficient evidence prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. (
) Paper records must be maintained until the examiner determines that the has no criminal fraud potential. Record (

) After uploading to RCCMS, you should keep the following paper records for any matter involving potential criminal fraud: • Records which contain color (such as blue ink, color letterhead). • Records in which the taxpayer used white-out or any alteration or markings that would render the scanned document not identical to original document. (

) Civil fraud results in a remedial action taken by the Government, such as assessing the correct tax and imposing civil penalties as an addition to tax, Criminal well as retrieving transferred assets. Civil penalties are assessed and administratively as part of the unpaid balance of assessment. (

) Criminal fraud results in a punitive action with penalties consisting of ﬁnes and/or imprisonment. Criminal penalties: • Are enforced only by prosecution • Are provided to punish the taxpayer for wrongdoings, and • Serve as a deterrent to other taxpayers. (
) A tax fraud offense may result in both civil and criminal penalties. may be ordered in criminal tax cases pursuant to a plea agreement or a viction under Title
of the United States Code (U.S.C.) and may be as a condition of probation. (

) Avoidance of tax is not a criminal offense. Taxpayers have the right to avoid, or minimize their taxes by legitimate means. One who avoids tax vs. Evasion not conceal or misrepresent, but rather shapes and pre-plans events to or eliminate tax liability within the parameters of the law.

Taxpayers who knowingly understate their tax liability often leave evidence in the form of identifying earmarks (or indicators). A sign or symptom that actions may have been done for the purpose of deceit, concealment or to make things seem other than what they are. Indications, in and of themselves, do not establish that a particular action was done.
Examples of fraud indicators include:
Substantial unexplained increases in net worth
Substantial excess of personal expenditures over resources
Bank deposits from unexplained sources substantially exceeding reported income
Documents that appear to be altered or false

a. Those actions that establish that a particular action was ately done for the purpose of deceit, subterfuge, camouﬂage, concealment, some attempt to color or obscure events, or things seem other than what they are. b. Examples include:
Omissions of speciﬁc items where similar items are included
Concealment of bank accounts or other assets
Failure to deposit receipts to business accounts
Covering up sources of receipts
Note: Fraud cannot be established without affirmative acts of

Joint Terrorism Task Force (JTTF) Cases – These cases are generally deﬁned as the unlawful use of force or violence against persons or property to intimidate or coerce a government, civilian population or any segment thereof in furtherance of political or social objectives that threaten our National Security. JTTF cases involve, but are not limited to: • Entities or individuals on the OFAC Specially Designated Nationals List. • Entities or individuals that have been identiﬁed by CI as potentially being involved in terrorism. • Grants and allocations being made to questionable organi- zations or individuals, either foreign or domestic. • Prohibited transactions involving OFAC-sanctioned countries. ) CI’s mission is to serve the American public by investigating potential violations of the IRC and related ﬁnancial crimes in a manner that fosters ﬁdence in the tax system and compliance with the law. (
) The primary objective of CI is the prosecution, conviction and incarceration individuals who violate criminal tax laws and commit related offenses. (
) Criminal prosecutions serve to enhance voluntary compliance. (

The initial conference between the referring examiner, the FTA, the evaluating special agent (SA), and/or the TFS allows the examiner the opportunity to explain the case in detail and address any questions regarding the potential criminal violations. CI will be provided access to all work papers and documents needed to effectively evaluate the referral during the initial conference. (
) The examiner will enter his/her name and grade, and enter the date the referral is being forwarded via secured e-mail to the examiner’s group manager. (

) The examiner’s group manager will review the referral, and if in agreement, ensure that the proper Area/Territory/Group is entered, approve the referral forward it via secured e-mail to the FTA and TFS for consideration. The iner’s group manager will retain a copy of the referral for the case ﬁle. (

) The FTA will review the referral, and if in agreement, will approve the referral and prepare a one-page narrative (used to describe additional facts or the fraud development process). If necessary, the FTA will embed the narrative in the Form
PDF ﬁle, and forward it via secured e-mail to the FTA group manager for consideration. (

) The FTA group manager will review the referral, and if in agreement, will approve the referral and enter the FTA Management Control Number and forward it via secure e-mail to the appropriate CI Field Office. (
) Within

workdays of receipt of the referral, the SA assigned to evaluate the referral will identify the subject (individual or entity under criminal consideration) as the primary investigation (PI), assign a PI number to the case and set up the initial conference. At that conference, the referring examiner, his/her group manager, the evaluating SA, his/her supervisory special agent (SSA), the FTA (if available), and/or the TFS will meet to the referral and review tax returns, evidence gathered to support the alleged offense, criminal tax computations, etc. Also, discuss the following issues at the initial conference: a. Veriﬁcation of income b. Explanations offered by the taxpayer, the taxpayer’s representative, and/or the return preparer concerning the alleged offense

b. There are two types of joint investigations, administrative (non- Grand Jury) and Grand Jury. Among the procedural distinctions are the roles and requirements that apply to mandatory quarterly (four-way) conferences. • Speciﬁc guidance for the examiner cooperating in adminis- trative joint investigations is found in IRM
, Administrative Joint Investigation. • Speciﬁc guidance for the examiner cooperating in Grand Jury investigations is found in IRM
, Federal Grand Jury Suspense Procedures. (

) All criminal investigations (administrative and Grand Jury) involving agents (joint investigations) are subject to mandatory quarterly (four-way) con- ferences. Four-way conferences are also required for all accepted criminal referrals (administrative and Grand Jury) in which an examiner is not asked to participate (non-joint investigations). In this scenario, the mandatory four-way conferences are designed to inform the referring compliance function of the updated investigation status. A status update for this purpose includes: the SA is writing the special agent’s report (SAR), discontinuing the case, case forwarded to Department of Justice (DOJ) - Tax or the Assistant United States Attorneys (AUSAs) office, case is going to trial, etc.). The SSA and the group manager of the cooperating agent will exercise sufficient control and follow-up to ensure the conferences are conducted and the investigation is promptly completed. The SSA should contact the EO or FSL/ET group manager to schedule the required four-way conference. If the SSA has not contacted the group manager to schedule a mandatory four-way conference when one is due, the group manager may also contact the SA to schedule a four-way con- ference. However, CI has primary responsibility for scheduling the mandatory four-way conference.

) This subsection discusses the procedures to follow in a civil fraud case. (
) A civil fraud penalty case may be developed based on facts and of a civil examination or result from a case initiated by CI. (

) Civil fraud penalties will be asserted when there is clear and convincing evidence to prove that some part of the underpayment of tax was due to Such evidence must show the taxpayer’s intent to evade the assessment of tax, which the taxpayer believed to be owing. Intent is distinguished from inad- vertence, reliance on incorrect technical advice, sincerely-held difference of opinion, negligence or carelessness. In the case of a joint return, intent must be established separately for each spouse as required by IRC

(c). The fraud of one spouse cannot be used to impute fraud by the other spouse. Thus, the civil fraud penalty may be asserted only on one spouse, unless is sufficient evidence that both spouses participated in the fraudulent act(s) resulting in the underpayment reported in their joint return. Note: When considering the civil fraud penalty, the fact that a taxpayer has not ﬁled and has tax due is not sufficient to assert the civil penalty. An act of fraud, as stated in IRM
, Indicators of Fraud vs Acts of Fraud, must also be present. (
) Speciﬁc guidance on fraud indicators and the development of fraud may be found in IRM
, Fraud Technical Advisors (FTA) and Deﬁnitions, and IRM
, Fraud Development Procedures. (

) Since direct proof of fraudulent intent is rarely available, fraud must be by circumstantial evidence and reasonable inferences. Fraud generally involves one or more of the following elements: • Deception • Misrepresentation of material facts • False or altered documents • Evasion (i.e., diversion or omission) (

) The courts focus on key badges of fraud in determining whether there was “intent to evade” tax. A determination of fraud is based on the taxpayer’s course of conduct, with each badge of fraud given the weight appropriate to particular case. An evaluation of fraud is based on the weight of the rather than the quantity of the factors. Some of the common “ﬁrst indicators badges) of fraud” include: • Understatement of income (e.g., omissions of speciﬁc items or entire sources of income, failure to report substantial amounts of income received) • Accounting irregularities (e.g., two sets of books, false entries on documents) • Obstructive actions of the taxpayer (e.g., false statements, of records, transfer of assets, failure to cooperate with the examiner, concealment of assets) • A consistent pattern over several years of underreporting taxable income • Implausible or inconsistent explanations of behavior • Engaging in illegal activities (e.g., drug dealing), or attempting to conceal illegal activities • Inadequate records • Dealing in cash • Failure to ﬁle returns, and • Education and experience

) Federal grand juries are convened for the purpose of inquiring into alleged criminal violations of Federal statutes. In the context of Federal tax Juries tions, a Grand Jury Request may be made where the administrative (the IRS investigation) cannot develop the relevant facts within a period of time. (

) The Internal Revenue Service, a United States Attorney, or a Strike Force Attorney may request to initiate a grand jury. The Service cannot initiate a grand jury investigation on its own. The Criminal Section of the Justice ment’s Tax Division approves grand jury investigations of suspected tax violations. (

) An attorney for the government, such as an Assistant United States may request the Service’s assistance in an ongoing or proposed grand jury investigation whenever information available to the attorney indicates commission of crimes. Within the Service, CI has jurisdiction over grand cases. Consequently, all such requests for Service assistance are made through CI. (

) Examples of information excluded from the secrecy restrictions of the Rules of Criminal Procedure include: • Interviews conducted and documents obtained by CI prior to referral the grand jury. • Information obtained by search warrants issued and executed prior to referral to the grand jury. • Affidavits sworn by the SA pursuant to securing a search warrant by the court. These affidavits reﬂect alleged offenses. Note: The Cooperating Grand Jury EO Agent should segregate all documents in the case ﬁle prepared by the Field Examiner assigned to the case prior to being identiﬁed as a grand jury case. This information should be forwarded through the Area Manager back to the TE/GE FSC for inclusion in the jury suspense ﬁle. (

) The second stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury Agent’s involvement is the Indictment Stage. An indictment is the formal document identifying the grand jury’s charges against the defendant. The indictment is a matter of public record (unless sealed). a. The Cooperating Grand Jury Agent, in cooperation with the Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA), should include complete civil assessment tion in the indictment. b. Depending on the charges alleged in the indictment, the AUSA may or may not be able to include this information in the indictment. c. If the case does not go to trial, the next opportunity for the Cooperating Grand Jury Agent to ensure that civil assessment information is preserved is during the plea agreement stage. (

) The third stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury EO Agent’s involvement is Plea Agreement Stage. a. Even though the Cooperating Grand Jury Agent usually does not pate in this stage, it is important that the Cooperating Grand Jury convey to the AUSA the importance of including speciﬁc civil information in the plea agreement. b. Plea negotiations generally result in the defendant pleading guilty to lesser charges. c. If there was limited disclosure of civil information in the indictment, the absence of speciﬁc civil assessment information in the plea agreement may result in the Field Examiner not having enough non-grand jury mation to propose adjustments, make assessments or provide information needed for the collection of taxes. d. Thus, the defendant may receive a criminal sentence but may not pay any tax and penalties due to lack of information in the public record. e. If speciﬁc civil assessment information is not made a matter of public record through the indictment or plea agreement, the last opportunity achieve this objective is during formal sentencing proceedings. (
) The fourth stage of the Cooperating Grand Jury Agent’s involvement is the Formal Sentencing Proceedings Stage.

record during this stage. One of the most important documents entered in the public record is the Government’s Version of the Facts. Information entered into the record during sentencing proceedings must be relevant to the question of guilt or assist the court in sentencing the defendant. In United States v. Alexander, 860 F.2d. 508 (2d. Cir. 1988), the court rejected the government’s argument that unlimited public disclosure of grand jury materials was permissible during sentencing proceedings. the court stated that "[a] party moving for a relaxation of the normal rule of secrecy should structure its request to cover only material that is needed." 860 F.2d at 513. This holding is consistent with the Supreme Court’s inter- pretation of Rule 6(e) to require a "strong showing of particularized need for grand jury materials before any disclosure will be permitted." United States Sells Engineering, Inc., 463 U.S. 418, 443 (1983).
